docs.snippet: There is a current fascination here with sentimental old tangos recalling bygone and better days. This drab but stately capital is a melancholy reminder that Uruguay was once a model of prosperity, well-being and democratic stability in. Latin...
docs.lead_paragraph: There is a current fascination here with sentimental old tangos recalling bygone and better days. This drab but stately capital is a melancholy reminder that Uruguay was once a model of prosperity, well-being and democratic stability in. Latin America.
docs.abstract: Article on the decline of Uruguay, once a model of prosperity and democratic stability in Latin Amer; capital of Montevideo representative of steady erosion of quality of life in Uruguay; tourism, 2d largest industry, declining; recent military coup d'etat, viewed apathetically by most Uruguayans, discussed; Uruguay is smallest country on the continent; population largely urban; Uruguay has very low population growth rate; history of Uruguay, and its great reformer Jose Batlle y Ordonez, discussed; natl decline traced to '53 slump in world prices for wool, meat and hides, Uruguay's main exports; expensive public services initiated by Batlle are cause of serious inflation; state corporations, employing 25% of labor force, notoriously inefficient; traditional political groups lack leadership; armed forces, called on to destroy Tupamaro guerrillas, asserted right to govern by staging coup; military leaders have 19-point 'program of natl reconstruction,' which is met with resignation by population as a whole

headline.main: Uruguayans, Their Life Ever More Drab, Are Apathetic After Coup

byline.original: By MARVINE HOWESpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: NEWARK-Two years ago, Juan and Rosa met and fell in love while working on a production line in a factory near here. They decided to marry.

docs.abstract: Thousands of illegal aliens live in New Jersey with fear of being apprehended by Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization and deported back to their native countries; great majority of illegal aliens enter US with tourist visas; informed sources maintain that discriminatory laws and immigration quotas prevent many foreigners from applying for citizenship

headline.main: Illegal Aliens:Thousands Fear Risk of Exposure; Most Are Hardworking An Unusual Case Illegal Aliens Live in Fear Living With Fear How the System Works

docs.lead_paragraph: Gulfstream Park opens a 55-day program tomorrow with the running of the $20,000 added Appleton Handicap in two divisions and the 1973 debut of the filly champion, La Prevoyante. La Prevoyante, unbeaten as a 2-year-old and Canada's horse of the year, will start in a six-furlong allowance sprint.
docs.abstract: S Africa returns to Davis Cup competition after 4 yrs by winning opening singles against Uruguay in S Amer Zone 1st round match on Mar 4 in Punta Del Este, Uruguay; S Africa was banned from cup competition in '70 because of its apartheid policies

docs.snippet: SEOUL, South Korea-South Koreans, who have been successful in building up their own economy with foreign financial help, are now investing their capital resources and knowhow in other less developed nations.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea-South Koreans, who have been successful in building up their own economy with foreign financial help, are now investing their capital resources and knowhow in other less developed nations.
docs.abstract: S Koreans, successful in bldg up their own econ with foreign financial help, are now investing their capital resources abroad; 23 S Korean cos are operating in 18 foreign countries and territories with total investment of $13-million; activities cover wide range of investments; 1st S Korean investment overseas was made in '68 by Korea Development Co; other Korean investors abroad, together with their enterprises, listed

headline.main: South Koreans Investing Abroad In Other Less-Developed Lands; First Investment in 1968

docs.snippet: Uruguayan security forces have announced the capture of four of the men involved in the 1970 kidnapping-murder of Dan A. Mitrione, an American police expert. The fifth man was killed in a clash with the police, they said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguayan security forces have announced the capture of four of the men involved in the 1970 kidnapping-murder of Dan A. Mitrione, an American police expert. The fifth man was killed in a clash with the police, they said.
docs.abstract: Uruguayan security forces announce capture of 4 men involved in '70 kidnapping-murder of D Mitrione, Amer police expert; Tupamaro guerrillas who kidnapped Mitrione demanded as ransom the release of all pol prisoners in Uruguay; Mitrione was killed when Uruguayan Govt refused; police say 5th man involved in crime was killed in clash with police

docs.snippet: Fifteen years ago, Brazil's production of automobiles was zero. Today Brazil has the largest automotive industry in Latin America and ranks eighth in the world. Production passed 400,000 units last year, with threequarters of them Volkswagens, but...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, Brazil's production of automobiles was zero. Today Brazil has the largest automotive industry in Latin America and ranks eighth in the world. Production passed 400,000 units last year, with threequarters of them Volkswagens, but the competition rising fast.
docs.abstract: Brazil's booming auto indus discussed; 15 yrs ago, Brazil's production of autos was zero; today it has largest auto indus in Latin Amer and ranks 8th in world; production passed 400,000 units in '72, with Volkswagen producing about 335,000 vehicles; there are 9 principal auto mfrs in Brazil, including GM, Ford and Chrysler; Fiat chmn G Agnelli recently signed agreement to build $230-million plant in collaboration with Brazilian Govt; plant will have capacity to turn out 190,000 cars per yr when completed in '75; booming auto indus is anomaly because annual per capita income is less than $450; it grew out of dreams of grandeur of former Pres J Kubitschek, who believed Brazil should mfr its own cars at any price and offered generous incentives to that end; major impetus to auto sales was creation of Consorcio, lottery-oriented credit system; indus grew during period of rampant inflation when people bought cars as investment with assurance that they would sell at profit; families bought cars collectively, with several working members chipping in to make purchase; even smallest cars are expensive because of high cost of skilled labor and high taxes; illus

headline.main: Brazil, Aided by Lottery, Forges Booming Auto Industry; Dreams and Building Brasilia
